notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
For students in LEC0201.

Note: On November 28th - TUT0202 will be held in SK 702.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the Spanish language for beginning students; overview of basic grammatical structures, development of vocabulary and oral and written expression. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish for Beginners
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: No previous knowledge of Spanish, or placement test results.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SPA120Y1, SPA219Y1, SPA319Y1, SPA220Y1, SPA320Y1, SPA420H1

courses.name: Accelerated Spanish Through Community Engaged Learning

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is a combination of SPA100Y1 and SPA220Y1 into one year. It is designed for students with prior knowledge of Spanish, but whose level is not appropriate to enroll in SPA220Y1. The focus is on the fundamentals of Spanish grammar and cultural aspects through community service learning with the local Spanish-speaking community of Toronto. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Accelerated Spanish Through Community Engaged Learning
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: High School Spanish; informal knowledge of Spanish
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Native and Heritage Speakers, SPA219Y1, SPA100Y1 and SPA220Y1

courses.name: Class and Work in the Americas

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines economic and social inequalities in the contemporary Americas. We look at the ways in which class divisions are represented in academic studies, literature, film, and television. From Mexican maquiladoras to indigenous reservations, we consider the global poor and how recent changes in the character of work (automation, outsourcing, free trade zones) have had an impact on class divisions, especially for younger members of society. Can a renewed understanding of class and work help us to negotiate power, privilege, and inequality in this century? Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Class and Work in the Americas

courses.name: War and Empire in the Hispanic World

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
October 31, 2019: Course Cancelled.
Please contact Dept for information.

cmCourseInfo.description: Spain built up a world empire in the sixteenth century, by unifying its monarchy in the Iberian peninsula and Europe and conquering territories in the New World. Writers and thinkers recorded the progress of this empire with praise, but they also commented on ethical issues related to rule over other peoples and the impact of armed violence on the lives of soldiers and civilians. We will study these questions by reading important Spanish texts that describe the conduct and impact of wars of conquest and of civil unrest. Through a focus on writings that deal with warfare, this course offers an introduction to an important period in European history. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: War and Empire in the Hispanic World

courses.name: A Brief History of Love in the Western World

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to the ways in which the foremost thinkers in the history of the Western world (Plato, Ovid, St. Augustine, Ficino, Ebreo) conceived the idea of love; how did the notions of sexuality and gender play into that idea, and how did these notions carry on – or not – into our present understanding of love, sexuality and gender. While the background readings pertain to the general Western cultural heritage, the literary texts through which we will observe particular applications of the theories of love were produced by some of the outstanding 16th and 17th century Spanish authors (for ex. Rodríguez de Montalvo; Jorge de Montemayor; Miguel de Cervantes; Tirso de Molina, María de Zayas, Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz). All the readings will be in English. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: A Brief History of Love in the Western World

courses.name: A Brief History of Love in the Western World

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to the ways in which the foremost thinkers in the history of the Western world (Plato, Ovid, St. Augustine, Ficino, Ebreo) conceived the idea of love; how did the notions of sexuality and gender play into that idea, and how did these notions carry on – or not – into our present understanding of love, sexuality and gender. While the background readings pertain to the general Western cultural heritage, the literary texts through which we will observe particular applications of the theories of love were produced by some of the outstanding 16th and 17th century Spanish authors (for ex. Rodríguez de Montalvo; Jorge de Montemayor; Miguel de Cervantes; Tirso de Molina, María de Zayas, Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz). All the readings will be in English. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: A Brief History of Love in the Western World

cmCourseInfo.description: For native (heritage) speakers who have had exposure to spoken Spanish in an informal context (i.e, living in a Spanish-speaking country; or with a Spanish-speaking family), but little to no exposure to written Spanish. The students' ability to speak and understand Spanish may range from basic to relatively high fluency, but they cannot write and/or read Spanish. The course reviews English/Spanish spelling differences; written and spoken registers of Spanish, and basic aspects of the grammatical system. Provides students with the essential understanding of Spanish grammatical system; builds their vocabulary; and trains them to express themselves formally.
cmCourseInfo.title: Academic Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Basic to relatively high native ability to speak and understand Spanish; limited or no formal education in Spanish.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students must enroll in the mandatory tutorial section on ACORN.

cmCourseInfo.description: Intermediate Spanish for non-native speakers. Intensive grammar review of the structures of Spanish integrated with an introduction to reading authentic Spanish material, with practice designed to build vocabulary and to improve oral and written expression.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA100Y1 or placement test.

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical introduction to articulatory phonetics, Spanish sound patterns, phonetics, phonology; the basic concepts of phonetic description and transcription; the study of Spanish vowel and consonant systems, stress and intonation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish Pronunciation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA100Y1
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SPA219Y1; native speakers of Spanish; SPA321H1

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to university literary studies in Spanish and information literacy. Representative selection of Spanish and Spanish American prose, poetry, and drama, with focus on critical terminology and methods of literary analysis. Required for a program degree.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literary Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: First semester SPA220Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to university literary studies in Spanish and information literacy. Representative selection of Spanish and Spanish American prose, poetry, and drama, with focus on critical terminology and methods of literary analysis. Required for a program degree.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literary Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: First semester SPA220Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: Forms of cultural expression in Spain, Latin America and Spanish-speaking North America, with study of representative media, including literature, journalism, film, visual art, and the urban environment. Introduction to methods of cultural analysis. (Offered in alternate years).
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Cultural Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 1st semester of SPA220Y1

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Room Change: September 23, 2019. Day/Time Changed: September 4, 2019.
Winter Term Room Changed: December 3, 2019.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Spanish for non-natives. Selective review of grammar with emphasis on the complex sentence; intensive practice in written and oral expression to improve proficiency.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or placement test.

cmCourseInfo.description: The basic concepts and analytic tools of linguistics applied to the study of Spanish, with a focus on the Spanish phonological, morphological, and syntactic systems. Theoretical discussion and practical exercises in analytic techniques.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Linguistics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1; or instructor's permission

cmCourseInfo.description: Analysis of the development of Spanish Cinema within its social and political contexts. Directors studied include Buñuel, Bardem, Erice, Saura, Almodóvar and Bigas Luna. (Offered every three years).
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish Cinema
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department

cmCourseInfo.description: Representative fiction by Galdós, the principal Spanish novelist of the nineteenth century. Detailed study of such texts as Marianela, Doña Perfecta, La desheredada, Realidad, La incognita, in relation to modernity of realist fiction and contemporary issues in politics, social relations and individual psychology. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Galdos and the Realist Novel
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department

courses.name: Parody and Comedy in Early Modern Spanish Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: Parody and comedy as interrelated literary forms that create humour through conventional character types, the play of language, self-conscious imitation, and the relationship of parodic works to canonical intertexts. Considerations of humour as a response to social anxieties in early modern Spain. Analysis of poems, plays and short prose narratives by representative authors; Garcilaso, Góngora, Quevedo, Tirso de Molina, Cervantes.
cmCourseInfo.title: Parody and Comedy in Early Modern Spanish Literature
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or permission of the Department

courses.name: Nation, Identity and Modernity in Spanish-America

cmCourseInfo.description: Analysis of poetry, short stories, essays, and graphic art in the context of nation-building and the question of identity during the nineteenth century. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Nation, Identity and Modernity in Spanish-America
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of representative works of major artistic and literary movements in 20th and 21st century Spanish America: avant-garde poetry, theatre of the absurd, surrealist art, neo-realism, postmodernism. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Avant-Garde Movements in Spanish America
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department

courses.name: Central American Literature: Narratives of War

cmCourseInfo.description: The 70s and 80s represent a period of armed struggle, civil war, and revolution in most of Central America. Through the study of specific novels, short stories, and films, this course analyzes the representation of violence, and the political repression generated by military conflicts. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Central American Literature: Narratives of War
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1  or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department

cmCourseInfo.description: Linguistic analysis with the objective of improving students' command of Spanish grammar. Advanced review of traditional grammatical topics, including the verbal and pronominal systems, and Spanish copulas and embedded clauses. This course assumes familiarity with the grammatical terminology introduced in SPA320Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Grammar
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA219Y1 or SPA320Y1, or placement test.

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of linguistic variation across the Spanish-speaking world; central issues in phonological, morphological, and syntactic variation, analyzed from a geographical as well as from a social point of view. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociolinguistics of Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA322H1 or permission of the department

cmCourseInfo.description: A course on specific topics in Spanish studies, designed for advanced students. Course content and instructor are established on a yearly basis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Spanish Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA220Y1/SPA219Y1

courses.name: Literature and Society in Medieval Iberia

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of medieval social topics such as witchcraft, violence, love, marriage, childhood, maternity, crimes and punishment. Analysis of such texts as Poema del Mio Cid; the Romancero, Milagros de Nuestra Señora, Libro de buen amor, Don Juan Manuel and Celestina, from the perspective of iconography and social history. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Literature and Society in Medieval Iberia
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.

courses.name: Transatlantic Hispanic Baroque: Crisis and Disenchantment

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of the seventeenth-century Transatlantic Hispanic world that, after the epoch of discovery and expansion in the sixteenth century, faces economic and political downfall, accompanied by a social and spiritual crisis that results in the culture baroque. Through analysis of literary texts by such authors as Cervantes, Góngora, Quevedo, Sor Juana, Sigüenza, Gracián Zayas and Calderón, we will discuss the meanings of the term "baroque", and of the phenomena that capture its zeitgeist.
cmCourseInfo.title: Transatlantic Hispanic Baroque: Crisis and Disenchantment
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA320Y1; at least one other 300-level course in SPA

cmCourseInfo.description: This course integrates a series of contemporary debates in Latin American cultural studies with analysis of its transdisciplinary history and global permutations. Key topics of investigation within these debates may include indigeneity; coloniality, transculturation, and subalternity; empire, nation, and globalism; revolution, state discourse, and the popular; gender and sexuality; and the production of race.
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin American Transculturations
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA258H1; SPA219Y1/SPA320Y1
